G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 186, §14, as the claim arises from a breach of the landlord’s statutory and common law duties under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises” by a tenant.

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is about commercial leases and the abandonment of the independent covenants rule in that context. It discusses residential tenancies only historically (e.g., Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway and the implied warranty of habitability), but does not state or analyze that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy. The proposition concerns residential leases and quiet enjoyment; this case concerns commercial leases and mutually dependent covenants, so it does not provide authority for the claimed rule.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "As it applied to residential leases, the independent covenants rule was completely supplanted in 1973, when we recognized that a residential 'lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises.' Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 198. 'These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations.'"

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment and analyzes what constitutes its breach, but it does not state that such a covenant is implied in *every residential tenancy in Massachusetts*. The court assumes the existence of the implied covenant in these particular leases and focuses on whether the landlords’ conduct constituted a breach/constructive eviction, not on the universal scope of the covenant across all residential tenancies. Therefore, it is not direct authority for the broad proposition claimed.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The loss of electrical service to one bedroom for over six weeks constituted a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address loss of electrical service or any physical defect affecting a single bedroom; instead it concerns drug activity in common areas and resulting interference with tenants’ use of exterior spaces. The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis speaks generally about serious interference (e.g., loss of use of sidewalks, streets, and recreational areas), not about electrical outages or any similar fact pattern. Therefore this case cannot be cited as authority that an electrical outage in one bedroom for six weeks constitutes substantial interference with use and enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The loss of electrical service to one bedroom for over six weeks constituted a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses loss of electrical service, a single bedroom, or a six‑week period; it concerns repeated sewage flooding of an apartment and the resulting emotional distress, warranty of habitability, and quiet enjoyment issues. While it recognizes that substantial interferences with use and enjoyment (here, recurrent flooding) can support liability, it does not hold or even mention that loss of electrical service to one bedroom for six weeks is a substantial interference. The proposition is therefore not accurately supported by this case.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” (Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 101-102, internal citations omitted.)

Aparicio v. Mangan, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 21.raw_text: Aparicio v. Mangan, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 210 (2005)
Aparicio v. Mangan, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 21.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely repair the electrical wiring, despite notice, amounted to an “act or omission” that constructively interfered with Plaintiff’s right of quiet enjoyment.
Aparicio v. Mangan, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 21.case_name: Amberwood Development Corp. v. Board of Appeals
Aparicio v. Mangan, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 21.support_reasoning: The opinion in Aparicio v. Mangan concerns the validity and as‑applied challenge of a zoning by-law under G.L. c. 240, § 14A; it does not involve landlord‑tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or any analysis of acts or omissions regarding repair obligations or electrical wiring. The court’s reasoning is focused on zoning uniformity, property injuries from land-use restrictions, and the standards for invalidating zoning provisions as applied, not constructive interference with quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about failure to repair electrical wiring constituting an act or omission interfering with quiet enjoyment.
Aparicio v. Mangan, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 21.relevant_excerpt: “The primary purpose of proceedings under § 14A is to determine how and with what rights and limitations the land of the person seeking an adjudication may be used under the provisions of a zoning enactment… The town argues that for a by-law provision to be found invalid as applied, the court must find both a failure to promote the purposes of the by-law and significant injury to the property owner… We conclude that there is, essentially, a second branch to the analysis, and we are persuaded by the town’s argument.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated his obligations under G.L. c. 239, §8A, which provides for remedies where a landlord fails to maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.351 (requiring that all habitable rooms be provided with electrical service).

105 C.M.R. 410.351.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated his obligations under G.L. c. 239, §8A, which provides for remedies where a landlord fails to maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.351 (requiring that all habitable rooms be provided with electrical service).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Failure to maintain such essential services constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, see Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997), Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982), and such interference, while not malicious, is actionable as an intentional omission once the landlord has notice.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The case does discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 and clarifies that negligent failure to repair known defects (after notice) can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not concern or mention ‘essential services’ as such. Its holding is that some degree of landlord fault (at least negligence, shown by notice or reason to know and failure to act) is required for a § 14 violation and that a bare statutory violation (here, the lead paint statute) is not enough. Thus, while it supports the “notice + negligent omission” aspect, it does not support the specific proposition that failure to maintain “essential services” constitutes a violation of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… [T]o obtain relief under § 14… it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Failure to maintain such essential services constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, see Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997), Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982), and such interference, while not malicious, is actionable as an intentional omission once the landlord has notice.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service—“constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment,” and it does so without requiring proof of malice or an intent to violate the covenant. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent or financial inability, controls and that liability arises whenever the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s action is interference with the tenant’s rights. This aligns with the proposition that failure to maintain essential services violates quiet enjoyment and is actionable as an intentional omission once the landlord has notice, even if not malicious.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s duty to preserve essential facilities includes a duty to make timely and effective repairs of wiring and electrical systems.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case discusses a landlord’s implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement where essential facilities (heat and hot water) fail, but it does not address wiring or electrical systems at all, nor does it focus on a specific duty to make timely and effective repairs. Its holding is about strict liability for maintaining habitable conditions and the timing of rent abatement once the landlord has notice, not about the scope of a duty to repair electrical wiring. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition regarding wiring and electrical systems.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[The warranty] means that at the inception of the rental there are no latent [or patent] defects in facilities vital to the use of the premises for residential purposes and that these essential facilities will remain during the entire term in a condition which makes the property livable.” Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 199, quoting from Kline v. Burns, 111 N.H. 87, 92 (1971).

Hemingway v. Waterson, 93 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Hemingway v. Waterson, 93 Mass. App. Ct. 101 (2018)
Hemingway v. Waterson, 93 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A landlord’s duty to preserve essential facilities includes a duty to make timely and effective repairs of wiring and electrical systems.
Hemingway v. Waterson, 93 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns suppression of a criminal defendant’s statements due to problems with language interpretation and Miranda warnings. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, essential facilities, or any duty to repair wiring or electrical systems. Nothing in the court’s reasoning or holding addresses a landlord’s maintenance obligations, so the case cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition.
Hemingway v. Waterson, 93 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "The constitutional principle at issue here is the due process requirement that an accused's statements in response to police questioning be voluntary. ... 'The Commonwealth bears the burden to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant's [statements were] voluntary.' ... For all of these reasons, we see no error in the judge's conclusion that the Commonwealth did not establish beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant's statement was voluntary."
